questions.text: The simplest way to distinguish radiation necrosis from a recurrence of a brain tumour is to look for
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PET scan A PET scan is the best way to distinguish radiation necrosis from a recurrence of a brain tumour.

Highyeild:

Radiation necrosis is a condition occurring in high-grade gliomas after radiotherapy that might mimic tumour recurrence, making clinicians' treatment decisions difficult. Convectional MRI sequences cannot distinguish between these two conditions. In compared to tumour recurrence, radiation necrosis may exhibit (but not necessarily) lower uptake on PET scans. As a result, brain biopsy is the greatest approach to distinguish between two entities.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. SPECT - Not used for this purpose Option C. CT - not preferred to distinguish radiation necrosis from a recurrence of a brain tumour. Option D. MRI - Convectional MRI sequences cannot distinguish between these two conditions

Extraedge:

A positron emission tomography (PET) scan is a type of imaging test. It uses a radioactive substance called a tracer to look for disease in the body. A PET scan shows how organs and tissues are working . This is different than MRI and CT scans. These tests show the structure of, and blood flow to and from organs.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man came to our emergency room with frequent and excruciating headaches. The patient was first given Metamizole intravenously and was closely observed. The discomfort did subside, but it reappeared four hours later. The patient's head was subjected to magnetic resonance imaging. Is a huge meningioma diagnosed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

“Mother-in-law” sign Meningiomas exhibit high contrast enhancement with early enhancement and delayed washout (early to arrive, late to disappear), a symptom known as the mother-in-law sign.

Highyeild:

Meningiomas are extra-axial tumors and represent the most common tumor of the meninges. They are a non-glial neoplasm that originates from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges and are located anywhere that meninges are found, and in some places where only rest cells are presumed to be located.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Owls eye sign- spinal cord ischemia Tiger eye sign- Halloverden spatz disease Spondylolisthesis of L5 on frontal pelvic radiograph with inverted Napoleon hot sign-b/I

Extraedge:

Meningiomas are thought to arise from meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells, which themselves arise from pluripotent mesenchymal progenitor cells, which accounts for the unusual location of primary extradural tumors 17,18. Although the majority of tumors are sporadic, they are also seen in the setting of previous cranial irradiation and of course in patients with neurofibromatosis type II (Merlin gene on Chromosome 22). Additionally, meningiomas demonstrate estrogen and progesterone sensitivity and may grow during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension arrives at the emergency room with abrupt onset weakness on his left side. What kind of preliminary inquiry would you demand?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT head In an emergency, a CT scan of the head is preferable to an MRI.

Highyeild:

A hypertensive emergency is very high blood pressure with potentially life-threatening symptoms and signs of acute damage to one or more organ systems (especially brain, eyes, heart, aorta, or kidneys). It is different from a hypertensive urgency by this additional evidence for impending irreversible hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - The D-dimer assay is used to evaluate the treatment of DIC and excessive clotting disorders, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) , pulmonary embolism (PE), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Extraedge:

The term hypertensive emergency is primarily used as a specific term for a hypertensive crisis with a diastolic blood pressure greater than or equal to 120 mmHg or systolic blood pressure greater than or equal to 180 mmHg. Hypertensive emergency differs from hypertensive urgency in that, in the former, there is evidence of acute organ damage. Both of these definitions had collectively been known as malignant hypertension, although this medical term is replaced.

questions.text: What is the most frequent pineal tumour?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Germinoma Germinoma is the most prevalent tumour of the pineal area.

Highyeild:

A type of tumor that begins in germ cells (cells that form sperm or eggs). Germinomas can occur in the ovaries or testicles or other parts of the body, but they occur most often in the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Pineocytoma is the most common tumour of the pineal parenchymal gland. Pineoblastoma/pineocytoma has peripheral calcification , whereas germinoma has core calcification.

Extraedge:

Germinomas are thought to originate from an error of development, when certain primordial germ cells fail to migrate properly. Germinomas lack histologic differentiation, whereas nongerminomatous germ-cell tumors display a variety of differentiation. Like other germ-cell tumors, germinomas can undergo malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 34 year old female presented to OPD with headache, vomiting. CT-scan shows slightly hyperdense extra-axial lesion. On further investigation, MRI showed the following finding. What is the appearance called as and what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dural tail sign, meningioma In the given clinical question, the female with symptoms of headache and vomiting and radiological signs suggestive of meningioma . The sign shown on MRI- Dural tail Hence the correct option is B.

Highyeild:

The dural tail sign occurs as a result of thickening and enhancement of the dura and is most often seen adjacent to a meningioma. Initially, the sign was felt to be pathognomonic of meningiomas, however, it has become increasingly noted to be present in many other conditions, although without the same regularity

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. and C are not correct as ice-cream cone appearance is seen in Glioblastoma multiformis. This dural tail sign is not seen in astrocytoma .

Extraedge:

Initially, the dural tail was thought to result from direct invasion of the dura by the tumor, however, subsequent studies demonstrated it to be predominantly a reactive process due to vascular congestion and edema . Having said that, the literature is still divided and a wide range of prevalence of tumor invasion of the dural tail has been reported (0-100%), with generally higher prevalences in WHO II (atypical) meningiomas 4,5 . This is further complicated by the presence of tumor cells in apparently normal dura adjacent to tumors 5.

questions.text: A 28 year old female presented with high grade fever, nausea and vomiting. His consciousness was not altered. On examination, he was having also neck rigidity. Kernig’s sign and Brudzinski sign was positive. Which of the following is the provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meningitis In the given question, the female presented with clinical features of meningitis as fever, nausea and vomiting. Signs like kernig’s sign and Brudzinski sign are also positive.

Highyeild:

The classic triad of meningitis consists of fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status, but not all patients have all three, and almost all patients have headache. Altered mental status can range from irritability to somnolence, delirium, and coma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Encephalitis- it cannot be the diagnosis as altered sensorium is not present in this patient. Rest of the clinical features can be present. Option B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage - it can have similar features as meningitis but fever will not be present.

Extraedge:

One of the physically demonstrable symptoms of meningitis is Brudzinski's sign . Severe neck stiffness causes a patient's hips and knees to flex when the neck is flexed. Kernig's sign is performed with the individual lying on their back with their hips and knees flexed and bent at a 90-degree angle. Next, the clinician will slowly extend and straighten one knee at a time. Resistance, pain, or an inability to extend the knee is indicative of a positive Kernig's sign.

questions.text: You are attending neurology OPD as an medicine PG resident. You observe two patients with similar clinical picture suggesting of encephalitis. Images are given below of the MRI as a part of further evaluation labelled as A for patient A and B for patient B. Which of the following is true regarding the diagnosis of these patients?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient A -HSV encephalitis, Patient B- JE

options.label: B
options.text: Patient A - JE, Patient B- HSV encephalitis

options.label: C
options.text: Both of them have HSV encephalitis

questions.correct_answer: A. Patient A -HSV encephalitis, Patient B- JE
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patient A -HSV encephalitis, Patient B- JE In The given clinical scenario, image A for patient A shows temporal lobe involvement which points towards HSV encephalitis and image B reveals thalamus involvement which suggests Japanese encephalitis. Hence the correct answer is option A.

Highyeild:

Herpes simplex encephalitis is an acute or subacute illness associated with focal or global cerebral dysfunction caused by herpes simplex viruses belonging to either type 1 (HSV-1) or type 2(HSV-2). The vast majority of herpes simplex encephalitis is caused by HSV-1, with HSV-2 constituting less than 10%.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Image A for patient A shows temporal lobe involvement which points towards HSV encephalitis and image B reveals thalamus involvement which suggests Japanese encephalitis. Hence OPTION B,C,D are incorrect

Extraedge:

The classic presentation of HSV encephalitis is of a fever, headache, altered consciousness, focal neurological signs and seizures. Intravenous aciclovir is an effective treatment, reducing mortality and morbidity.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient presented with hypokinesia , rigidity and postural instability . considering the diagnosis, he was started on L-DOPA therapy, but he did not showed any improvement. Later it was also found that he had problem in moving his eyes in vertical direction. Diagnosis of supranuclear palsy was made. Which of the following image shows characteristic MRI appearance found in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A In the given question, as given the clinical diagnosis as progressive supranuclear palsy. The characterstic MRI appearance in this is known as ‘ humming Bird sign’ . which is shown in image A.

Highyeild:

The hummingbird sign , also known as the penguin sign , refers to the appearance of the brainstem in patients with progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP). The atrophy of the midbrain results in a profile of the brainstem (in the sagittal plane) in which the preserved pons forms the body of the bird, and the atrophic midbrain the head, with beak extending anteriorly towards the optic chiasm. Midbrain atrophy is best confirmed with reduction in the midbrain to pons ratio.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Hot cross bun sign is seen in multi-system atrophy. Option B. Panda sign is seen in Wilson disease. Option C. Dawson finger sign is seen in multiple sclerosis.

Extraedge:

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurodegenerative condition. It is an important differential diagnosis of Parkinson's disease (PD). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in PSP patients may reveal significant midbrain atrophy with sparing of pons known as “hummingbird” sign.

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient has history of recurrent attacks of tingling sensation in spine and limbs on neck flexion, Delirium ,dizziness, vertigo and blurring of vision. On examination of eyes she has RAPD. Her MRI showed new and old lesions at different sites as given below. Which is more associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multiple sclerosis It is a Demyelination disorder of CNS which is more common in females characterised by CNS lesions separated in time and space affecting different parts of brain and spinal cord. Relative afferent pupillary defect gives evidence of optic neuritis and other clinical features in correlation with MRI suggest it is multiple sclerosis.

Highyeild:

n MS, resulting nerve damage disrupts communication between the brain and the body. Multiple sclerosis causes many different symptoms, including vision loss, pain, fatigue and impaired coordination . The symptoms, severity and duration can vary from person to person. Some people may be symptom free for most of their lives, while others can have severe, chronic symptoms that never go away. Physiotherapy and medication that suppress the immune system can help with symptoms, and slow disease progression.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Optic neuritis: it is one if the clinical presentation of Multiple sclerosis, isolated optic neuritis will not have focal neurological deficit. Option: C. Parkinson’s disease: it is a movement disorder mostly diagnosed Clinically. Structural imaging like CT and MRI are rarely helpful. Option: D. Stroke: It is an acute medical emergency which is a sudden onset disease and rapidly reaches maximum severity. CT scanning is the mainstay of imaging in emergency stroke.

Extraedge:

Multiple sclerosis ( MS ) is the most common demyelinating disease, in which the insulating covers of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord are damaged . This damage disrupts the ability of parts of the nervous system to transmit signals, resulting in a range of signs and symptoms, including physical, mental, and sometimes psychiatric problems. Specific symptoms can include double vision, visual loss, muscle weakness, and trouble with sensation or coordination. MS takes several forms, with new symptoms either occurring in isolated attacks (relapsing forms) or building up over time (progressive forms). In the relapsing forms of MS, between attacks, symptoms may disappear completely, although some permanent neurological problems often remain, especially as the disease advances

questions.text: Which of the following Imaging technique can be used for neurochemical and metabolic assessment?
questions.correct_answer: C. PET scan and SPECT scan
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PET scan and SPECT scan PET scans display glucose metabolism in Dementia and Epilepsy. SPECT scan uses lipid soluble properties of radioactive tracers to mark cerebral blood flow.

Highyeild:

The main difference between SPECT and PET scans is the type of radiotracers used. While SPECT scans measure gamma rays, the decay of the radiotracers used with PET scans produce small particles called positrons. A positron is a particle with roughly the same mass as an electron but oppositely charged.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. X rays: are used for fractures and foreign bodie s in CNS Option: B. CT scan: is good for demonstrating bone and calcification Option: D. Useful for producing high quality soft tissue images, posterior fossa of skull and temporal lobes.

Extraedge:

Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging is routinely used and is the primary functional imaging tool used to evaluate the heart. More recently, positron emission tomography (PET) has been applied to the study of the heart and its uses continue to expand.

questions.text: On investigation, the CT scan of an 60 year old male patient with history of hypertension who is on irregular antihypertensive medication showed lncreased density in Basal ganglia and interventricular area as in the images given below: possible diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intracranial Haemorrhage In older people, commonly due to hypertension, small perforating vessels in the brain rupture into the Basal ganglia and ventricles causing Intracerebral Hemorrhage

Highyeild:

An intracranial hemorrhage occurs when an artery inside the skull leaks or ruptures . Bleeding in or around the brain called a cerebral (b)rain hemorrhage. The main causes of intracranial hemorrhage are: Hypertension (high blood pressure).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Brain tumour: calcified or highly proteinaceous material in tumours and by contrast enhancement they can be easily differentiated from intracerebral hemorrhage Option: B. Subdural hematoma: are mostly post traumatic and due to rupture of aneurysms and on CT scan have a typical crescent shaped presentation, with a concave surface away from skull. Option: C. Extradural hematomas : are also usually post traumatic and are typically biconvex in shape on CT scanning.

Extraedge:

Trauma is the most common cause of intracranial hemorrhage. It can cause epidural hemorrhage, subdural hemorrhage, and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Other condition such as hemorrhagic parenchymal contusion and cerebral microhemorrhages can also be caused by trauma. Non-traumatic causes of hemorrhage includes: hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, hemorrhagic conversion of ischemic infarction, cerebral aneurysms, dural arteriovenous fistulae, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, cerebral vasculitis and mycotic aneurysm. More than half of all cases of intracranial hemorrhage are the result of hypertension

questions.text: True/false. NCCT is the initial investigation of choice in any stroke patient. Hyperdense MCA sign is a sign of acute infarct on MRI. Thrombolysis is contraindicated in haemorrhagic stroke. DWI is the most sensitive sequence for acute stoake. Window period for iv thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke is 4.5 hours according to ECASS III trial. Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TFTT Stroke is defined by a reduction in blood flow to the brain. NCCT is the first IOC for stroke patients to distinguish between haemorrhagic and ischemic stroke. DWI sequence on MRI is most sensitive for detection of acute infarct. Signs of acute infarct on NCCT Hyperdense MCA sign Sylvian dot sign Obscuration of lentiform nucleus Insular ribbon sign In the case of a hemorrhagic stroke, IV thrombolysis is not recommended.

questions.text: A 40-year-old guy with a loss of consciousness presented to the emergency room. RTA had been mentioned by a patient's relative. The patient is an alcoholic with a high blood pressure. The NCCT head appeared to be in good condition. GCS is an eight-digit number. Urgent MRI [details below] is conducted. Isn't that what is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diffuse axonal injury Multiple blooming foci are seen diffusely affecting the bilateral cerebral hemisphere, mostly at the gray-white matter junction, on MRI imaging As per clinical history, most probable diagnosis DAI. Blooming artefact is a susceptibility artefact seen is on some MRI sequences when paramagnetic compounds affecting the local magnetic milieux are present. Despite the fact that it is an artefact, it could be used to improve the detection of certain tiny lesions. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy occurs in people who are above 65 years old.

Highyeild:

Diffuse axonal injury ( DAI ) is a brain injury in which scattered lesions occur over a widespread area in white matter tracts as well as grey matter. DAI is one of the most common and devastating types of traumatic brain injury and is a major cause of unconsciousness and persistent vegetative state after severe head trauma. It occurs in about half of all cases of severe head trauma and may be the primary damage that occurs in concussion. The outcome is frequently coma, with over 90% of patients with severe DAI never regaining consciousness. Those who awaken from the coma often remain significantly impaired.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Opiton A. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy Opiton B. SAH Opiton D. SDH The NCCT HEAD appeared to be in good condition. GCS is an eight-digit number suggests Diffuse axonal injury,hence other options are incorrect

Extraedge:

DAI is the result of traumatic shearing forces that occur when the head is rapidly accelerated or decelerated, as may occur in car accidents, falls, and assaults. Vehicle accidents are the most frequent cause of DAI ; it can also occur as the result of child abuse such as in shaken baby syndrome.
